questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic tingling and numbness in his right hand for the past 3 months. His symptoms are worse in the evening. There is no history of trauma. He is employed as a carpenter. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He drinks a pint of vodka daily. He does not use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased pinch strength in the right hand. Sensations are decreased over the little finger and both the dorsal and palmar surfaces of the medial aspect of the right hand. Which of the following is the most likely site of nerve compression?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In occupations that involve hammering and lifting heavy objects, such as carpentry, the ulnar nerve can be compressed proximally within the cubital tunnel (cubital tunnel syndrome) as a result of repetitive elbow flexion, which decreases the volume of the cubital tunnel. Decreased pinch strength occurs as a result of the weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, which appears as the Froment sign.

A positive Tinel sign at the medial epicondyle and findings on nerve conduction studies help to identify the level of nerve compression and confirm the diagnosis. Treatment of ulnar cubital tunnel syndrome consists of NSAIDs, behavior modification, wearing of an elbow pad, bracing at night to prevent overbending, and, in severe cases, surgical decompression.
Image Description:

The patient is asked to tightly pinch a piece of paper between the tips of the thumb and index finger or, as shown here, between the thumb and the second metacarpal. Inability to keep the thumb's interphalangeal joint extended while performing this maneuver is referred to as the “Froment sign,” which occurs with ulnar nerve palsy because the flexor pollicis longus (innervated by the median nerve) compensates for the action of the weak adductor pollicis (innervated by the ulnar nerve).

B) INCORRECT:

The pronator teres and its humeral and ulnar heads are located ventrally on the forearm near the cubital fossa. At this level, the ulnar nerve lies more medially, in close proximity to the origin of the ulnar and humeral heads of the flexor carpi ulnaris.

Between the heads of the pronator teres, the median nerve can be compressed (pronator teres syndrome), which can result in tingling and weakness in the hand. However, weakness in the hand would be restricted to the movements controlled by thenar muscles (e.g., thumb flexion and abduction), and paresthesias/sensory loss would be restricted to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the lateral half of the ring finger, and the lateral half of the palm. Moreover, finger flexion, pronation of the forearm, and, in some cases, volar flexion of the wrist would also be impaired. Also, pronator teres syndrome typically occurs in women above the age of 40.

C) INCORRECT:

The radial groove contains the radial nerve, not the ulnar nerve. Radial nerve compression can also result in sensory deficits, paresthesias, and/or weakness in the hand. However, the sensory symptoms would be restricted to the lateral two-thirds of the dorsal surface of the hand, and weakness would primarily affect supination and wrist and finger extension. Moreover, radial nerve palsy due to compression at the radial groove (e.g., Saturday night palsy) usually has an acute onset.

D) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve within the Guyon canal (ulnar tunnel syndrome) can also result in decreased pinch strength (due to adductor pollicis weakness) as well as sensory deficits or paresthesias over the little finger and, in some cases, the palmar surface of the medial aspect of the hand. However, the dorsal surface of the hand would be spared because the dorsal surface of the medial aspect of the hand is usually innervated by the dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve, which arises more proximally in the forearm. Moreover, ulnar tunnel syndrome typically occurs as a result of direct compression of the Guyon canal (e.g., in professional cyclists due to constant compression against the handlebar).

E) INCORRECT:

The supinator muscle and its two heads are located laterally near the radiocapitellar joint. At this level, the ulnar nerve lies medially, in close proximity to the humeroulnar joint as well as the origins of the two heads of the flexor carpi ulnaris.

Between the heads of the supinator muscle, the posterior interosseus nerve (PIN) can be compressed (PIN syndrome), which can result in weakness of the hand. However, the weakness would primarily involve wrist and finger extension. Sensory deficits or paresthesias would not be expected, as the PIN is a motor branch of the radial nerve.

F) INCORRECT:

The ulnar nerve courses above the flexor retinaculum, which forms the roof of the carpal tunnel. It cannot, therefore, be compressed within the carpal tunnel. Compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome) would manifest with sensory deficits, paresthesias, and/or weakness in the hand. However, the weakness would only affect movements controlled by thenar muscles (e.g., thumb flexion or abduction) and paresthesias or sensory loss would be restricted to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the lateral half of the ring finger, and the lateral half of the palm. Moreover, carpal tunnel syndrome typically occurs in professions that involve repetitive flexion-extension of the wrist or compression of the ventral surface of the wrist against a hard surface (e.g., computer workers).
questions.hint: Decreased pinch strength and sensory deficits over the little finger and both the dorsal and palmar surfaces of the medial aspect of the right hand suggest ulnar nerve entrapment.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic tingling and numbness in his right hand for the past 3 weeks. He says that he cannot hold a pen very well and that this is affecting his handwriting. The symptoms started after he played in a football game. Physical examination shows decreased pinch strength in the right hand. Sensation to light touch is decreased over the right little finger and the medial palmar surface of the right hand. Radiologic evaluation in this patient is most likely to show a fracture in which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injury to the capitate bone may occur after falling onto an outstretched hand. However, isolated fractures are very rare (3% of all carpal fractures) and patients typically present with pain on the dorsum of the wrist or proximal hand. Neurovascular compromise is possible with dislocation and typically affects the median nerve; the ulnar nerve is very unlikely to be affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Trapezoid bone fractures usually occur as a result of high energy trauma (e.g., when a player dives for an opponent with an outstretched arm). However, they are overall very rare (< 2% of all carpal fractures) and typically present with radial-dorsal wrist pain. There may be involvement of the radial and median nerve, but the ulnar nerve is very unlikely to be affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Injury to the trapezium bone is rare (only ∼4% of all carpal fractures) but can occur from axial loading or hyperextension of an adducted thumb. Trapezium bone fracture could cause injury to the median nerve, but the ulnar nerve would be unlikely to be affected.

D) INCORRECT:

Scaphoid bone fractures are common (60-70% of all carpal fractures) and can occur following a fall onto the outstretched hand (hyperextension). Scaphoid fractures can involve the radial artery (positive Allen test), but nerve injury is uncommon.

E) INCORRECT:

As the lunate bone lies well protected in the proximal row of carpal bones, fractures are very rare (only ∼4% of all carpal bone injuries). Injury due to a fall onto the extended wrist (hyperextension injury) could cause median nerve injury, but ulnar nerve injury would be very unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Fracture of the pisiform bone can occur from a fall onto the outstretched hand when the wrist is extended, or when the heel of the hand is used to strike or swing an object (e.g., baseball bat, golf club, or racquet). The pisiform bone marks the ulnar border of Guyon's canal, and a fracture could thus result in injury to the ulnar nerve. However, fractures to the pisiform bone are extremely rare (< 1% of carpal bone fractures) and so fracture to a different bone is much more likely to be the cause of his symptoms.

G) CORRECT:

Blunt trauma to the hook of hamate (e.g., fall on an outstretched hand) can lead to entrapment of the ulnar nerve, which is referred to as a distal ulnar lesion. In addition to paresthesias, numbness, weakness, and pain, this lesion can also cause ulnar claw deformity.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
questions.hint: Decreased pinch strength and sensory deficits over the little finger and palmar surfaces of the medial aspect of the right hand are suggestive of ulnar nerve entrapment at the level of the wrist.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent tingling of his hand. He is an avid cyclist and has recently started training for a cycle marathon. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength in the right hand and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. On asking the patient to grasp a piece of paper between his right thumb and right index finger in the first web space, there is hyperflexion of the right thumb interphalangeal joint. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over dorsal aspect of 1st web space
Inability to flex the index finger at the interphalangeal joints
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the medial half of the hand
Inability to extend the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint
Inability to extend the little finger at the proximal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensation in the dorsal web space between the thumb and index finger is often examined to assess intact radial nerve sensation. It would not be affected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the index finger at either the proximal or distal interphalangeal joints requires the action of the flexor digitorum superficialis (proximal joint) or flexor digitorum profundus (proximal and distal joints). The flexor digitorum superficialis and the lateral aspect of the flexor digitorium profundus (which flexes the index and middle finger) are innervated by the median nerve and would be unaffected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

C) INCORRECT:

The dorsum of the medial half of the hand (ring and small fingers) is innervated by the dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve, which arises in the forearm proximal to the passage of the ulnar nerve through Guyon canal. As this patient exhibits nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal, the sensory innervation to the medial half of the dorsum of the hand will remain intact.

D) INCORRECT:

Extension of the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint is mediated by the action of the extensor digitorum muscle, which is innervated by the radial nerve. The function of this muscle would not be affected by ulnar nerve compression.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's physical examination is suggestive of long-term ulnar nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal (Guyon canal syndrome), which is common in avid cyclists due to long-term pressure of the wrist against bike handlebars. This compression disrupts innervation to the ulnar innervated intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbricals, which are responsible for little finger extension at the proximal interphalangeal joint. Additional physical exam findings typically seen in this syndrome include numbness of the palmar surface of the small and ring fingers.

While splinting, cortisone injections, and NSAIDs may improve this patient's complaints, surgical release of the volar carpal ligament is required in refractory cases.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
questions.hint: A positive Froment sign (hyperflexion of the thumb due to paralysis of the adductor pollicis and unopposed action of flexor pollicis longus) and wasting of the hypothenar eminence are suggestive of ulnar nerve entrapment.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old guitarist presents with a 2-month history of progressive weakness in her left hand. She reports difficulty bringing her ring and little fingers toward her middle finger while playing, resulting in clumsy chord transitions. She occasionally experiences a tingling sensation in her palm and medial fingers, and notes reduced grip strength. On examination, she cannot maintain finger adduction against resistance, and there is sensory loss over the medial aspect of her hand.
Which nerve is most likely compromised?

choices.text: Radial nerve at the spiral groove
Median nerve at the carpal tunnel
Anterior interosseous nerve at the heads of pronator teres

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve lesions at the spiral groove typically cause wrist drop and sensory deficits over the dorsal lateral hand.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel causes numbness and tingling in the thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the ring finger, along with thenar muscle weakness.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms of weakness in finger adduction, sensory loss over the medial hand, and tingling in the ring and little fingers suggest ulnar nerve dysfunction. The ulnar nerve innervates the interossei muscles, responsible for finger adduction, and provides sensation to the medial hand. Compression at Guyon's canal in the wrist can lead to both motor and sensory deficits, often seen in individuals with repetitive hand use, such as guitarists.

Key learning point: The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the interossei muscles, which are crucial for the adduction of the fingers.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior interosseous nerve, a motor branch of the median nerve, affects forearm muscles and pinch grip but does not provide sensory innervation.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents to the office with a 3-week history of episodic tingling and numbness in his right hand. He says that he cannot hold a pen very well and that this is affecting his handwriting. The symptoms started after he played in a football game. Osteopathic structural examination reveals:

Decreased sensation to light touch over the dorsal and palmar aspects of the right fifth digit 

Decreased pinch strength in the right hand

3/5 muscle strength of the right hand in finger abduction and adduction
Hypertonicity of the right hypothenar muscles

Radiologic evaluation in this patient is most likely to reveal a fracture of which of the following labeled bones in the radiograph of a normal hand?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Blunt trauma to the hook of hamate (e.g., fall on an outstretched hand) can lead to entrapment of the ulnar nerve, which is referred to as a distal ulnar lesion. In addition to paresthesias, numbness, weakness, and pain, this lesion can also cause ulnar claw deformity.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

B) INCORRECT:

Trapezoid bone fractures usually occur as a result of high energy trauma (e.g., when a player dives for an opponent with an outstretched arm). However, they are overall very rare (< 2% of all carpal fractures) and typically present with radial-dorsal wrist pain. There may be involvement of the radial and median nerve, but the ulnar nerve is very unlikely to be affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Fracture of the pisiform bone can occur from a fall onto the outstretched hand when the wrist is extended, or when the heel of the hand is used to strike or swing an object (e.g., baseball bat, golf club, or racquet). The pisiform bone marks the ulnar border of Guyon's canal, and a fracture could thus result in injury to the ulnar nerve. However, fractures to the pisiform bone are extremely rare (< 1% of carpal bone fractures) and so fracture to a different bone is much more likely to be the cause of his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Scaphoid bone fractures are common (60-70% of all carpal fractures) and can occur following a fall onto the outstretched hand (hyperextension). Scaphoid fractures can involve the radial artery (positive Allen test), but nerve injury is uncommon.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the capitate bone may occur after falling onto an outstretched hand. However, isolated fractures are very rare (3% of all carpal fractures) and patients typically present with pain on the dorsum of the wrist or proximal hand. Neurovascular compromise is possible with dislocation and typically affects the median nerve; the ulnar nerve is very unlikely to be affected.

F) INCORRECT:

Injury to the trapezium bone is rare (only ∼4% of all carpal fractures) but can occur from axial loading or hyperextension of an adducted thumb. Trapezium bone fracture could cause injury to the median nerve, but the ulnar nerve would be unlikely to be affected.

G) INCORRECT:

As the lunate bone lies well protected in the proximal row of carpal bones, fractures are very rare (only ∼4% of all carpal bone injuries). Injury due to a fall onto the extended wrist (hyperextension injury) could cause median nerve injury, but ulnar nerve injury would be very unlikely.
questions.hint: Positive Froment sign (decreased pinch strength), weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles, and sensory deficits over the fifth digit of the right hand are suggestive of ulnar nerve entrapment at the level of the wrist.
